title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: sigscores helpful package providing easy way compute summary scores gene signatures. one main function ?computeSigScores, can used compute available scores.

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: Firstly, load sigscores needed packages:
code: library(sigscores) #>  #> Attaching package: 'sigscores' #> The following object is masked from 'package:methods': #>  #>     getPackageName

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: Now want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results vignette. can specify seed calling ?set.seed.
code: #Set a seed for RNG set.seed(   #A seed   seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value   #The kind of RNG to use   kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value   #The kind of Normal generation   normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value )

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: list currently supported scores available ?getAvailableScores function call. can extract ids selecting id column.
code: #list methods summary.scores = getAvailableScores()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = summary.scores) #learning method ids summary.scores.ids = summary.scores$id  #print print(summary.scores.ids) #>  [1] "mean"            "trimmedMean"     "weightedMean"    "IQM"             #>  [5] "median"          "mode"            "midrange"        "midhinge"        #>  [9] "trimean"         "briskow"         "reviewedBriskow" "weightedSum"     #> [13] "ssGSEA"          "gsva"            "plage"           "zscore"

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: create now simulated data use. vignette, consider matrix 100 genes 10 samples. can inspect data using ?head function, returns first parts vector, matrix, table, data frame function. Let’s print first 6 rows matrix. can now define gene signature. example, can randomly select genes matrix. Let’s select 20 genes.
code: #number of samples nc = 10 #number of genes nr = 100 #create matrix x = matrix(   data = sample(x = nr*nc),   nrow = nr,   ncol = nc,   dimnames = list(     paste0("g",seq_len(nr)),      paste0("S",seq_len(nc))   ) ) #print head(x = x, n = 6L) #>     S1  S2  S3  S4  S5  S6  S7  S8  S9 S10 #> g1 993 702 660 854 769 859 940 679 946 218 #> g2 585 620 941 714 994 369 602 506 981 674 #> g3 175 779 984 834 460 292 445 953 491 673 #> g4 778 855 293 140  29 601 980  82 161 115 #> g5 876  32 838  22 803 804 355 663  11 731 #> g6 835 462 894 560 885  88 442 199 541 725 #number of genes in signature ng = 20  #select genes signature = rownames(x)[sample(x = seq_len(nr), size = ng)]  #print signature #>  [1] "g12" "g41" "g23" "g59" "g93" "g70" "g51" "g53" "g20" "g72" "g78" "g48" #> [13] "g67" "g46" "g36" "g7"  "g13" "g15" "g45" "g33"

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: Finally, can compute summary scores. change default arguments specific score function, can use args: argument accept named list, name element must match id score want compute. example, may want compute trimmed mean considering specific fraction elements trimmed end. Looking documentation ?computeSigScores see internal function computing trimmed mean called ?trimmedMeanScores, accepts argument trim. can pass argument ?computeSigScores via args:

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: may want understand computed scores due selected genes signature, might ended similar scores also different lists genes. associate significance computed scores can use resampling method. idea calculate probability observing resampling value extreme one calculated original data. main steps involved process : Draw random samples original data Compute summary scores simulated data Create sampling distribution score Calculate significance score facilitate computation, ?computeSigScores can also calculate summary scores data sets generated using resampling. Two techniques provided ---box ?computeSigScores: permutation (.e. sampling without replacement) bootstrap (.e. sampling replacement). main new arguments need set sampling, indicates technique want use, n.repeat, tells function many random samples want generate. Let’s create summary scores 10 data sets generated using sampling without replacement. use bootstrap instead, just need change sampling argument.

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: sigscores provides simple approach speed computation multi-core computer via usage parallel, doParallel, foreach R packages. enable parallel execution just need set argument cores ?computeSigScores function integer greater 1. example, let’s try use 2 cores. note, function internally perform checks setting parallel environment, provided number cores high set cores maximum number available (logical) processors machine minus 1.
code: #compute summary scores with parallel execution scores = sigscores::computeSigScores(   x        = x,   i        = signature,   na.rm    = T,   scores   = summary.scores.ids,   sampling = "permutation",   n.repeat = 2,   cores    = 2 )

title: An introduction to `sigscores`
text: see advantage using parallel execution comparing computation time serial parallel setting higher number repeats. time execution function calls can use ?system.time R function. Let’s consider 500 permutations original data compute scores serial fashion first. Now can run parallel execution number repeats selecting 5 cores. Considering don’t need results parallel execution order, can set argument .inorder FALSE since can improve performance. Finally, can compare execution time. laptop following hardware: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8650 CPU @ 1.90GHz, 2112MHz, 4 Core(s), 8 Logical Processor(s) 1TB SSD Hard Drive 16GB RAM execution times serial parallel computations : parallel execution around 2.19 times faster serial execution.
code: #compute summary scores time_serial = system.time(   expr = {     scoresS = sigscores::computeSigScores(       x        = x,       i        = signature,       na.rm    = T,       scores   = summary.scores.ids,       sampling = "permutation",       n.repeat = 500     )   } ) #compute summary scores time_parallel = system.time(   expr = {     scoresP = sigscores::computeSigScores(       x        = x,       i        = signature,       na.rm    = T,       scores   = summary.scores.ids,       sampling = "permutation",       n.repeat = 500,       cores    = 5,       .inorder = FALSE     )   } ) #create a matrix m = rbind(   serial   = time_serial,   parallel = time_parallel )  #print print(m) #>          user.self sys.self elapsed user.child sys.child #> serial      176.97     0.30  180.19         NA        NA #> parallel      1.41     2.47   82.31         NA        NA

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alessandro Barberis. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Barberis (2022). sigscores: Compute Summary Scores Gene Signatures. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {sigscores: Compute Summary Scores for Gene Signatures},   author = {Alessandro Barberis},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: Compute Summary Scores for Gene Signatures
title: Compute Summary Scores for Gene Signatures
text: sigscores R package providing ready--use functions compute summary scores. idea behind sigscores provide single R package different summary scores allowing easy computation comparison metrics. Different strategies currently supported, common mean, median, mode scores.

title: Compute Summary Scores for Gene Signatures
text: can install latest development version GitHub (requires devtools package):
code: if (!require("devtools")) {   install.packages("devtools") }  devtools::install_github(   repo = "alebarberis/sigscores",    dependencies = TRUE,    build_vignettes = FALSE )

title: Compute Summary Scores for Gene Signatures
text: just getting started sigscores recommend starting Getting Started section site.

title: Plot Summary Scores as Box Plots — boxplotSigScores
code: boxplotSigScores(   data,   scores = NULL,   add.violin = F,   add.boxplot = T,   boxplot.width = 0.1,   add.scores = F,   scores.shape = 16,   scores.jitter.w = 0.2,   scores.jitter.h = NULL,   labs.title = "Summary Scores",   labs.x = "Summary Scores",   labs.y = "Scores",   labs.col = "Summary\nScores",   axis.text.x.angle = 90,   axis.text.x.size = 9,   axis.text.y.angle = 0,   axis.text.y.size = 9,   ... )

title: Plot Summary Scores as Box Plots — boxplotSigScores
code: #Set seed set.seed(seed = 5381L)  #Define row/col size n = 10  #Create input matrix x = matrix(  data = stats::runif(n = n*n, min = 0, max = 100),  nrow = n,  ncol = n,  dimnames = list(     paste0("g",seq(n)),     paste0("S",seq(n))  ) )  #Compute Summary Scores x = computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x) )  #Plot scores boxplotSigScores(data = x) #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing non-finite values (stat_boxplot). #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Achieved Significance Level (ASL) — computeASL
text: function computes approximate achieved significance level (ASL) permutation test bootstrap hypothesis test.

title: Achieved Significance Level (ASL) — computeASL
text: obs numerical vector containing observed value test statistic rnd numerical vector containing permutation/bootstrap replication statistics alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less"

title: Achieved Significance Level (ASL) — computeASL
text: numerical value representing approximate achieved significance level (ASL) test.

title: Achieved Significance Level (ASL) — computeASL
text: computed : $$\hat{ASL}_{sample}(x) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n}  {\hat{\theta}_{}}^{*} \ge \hat{\theta}$$ \(\hat{\theta}\) test statistic; \({\hat{\theta}}^{*}\) permutation/bootstrap distribution \(\hat{\theta}\); \({\hat{\theta}_{}}^{*}\) computed statistic \(\)-th permutation/boostrap vector. \(\hat{\theta}\) observed, ASL test represents probability observing least large value null hypothesis true.

title: Achieved Significance Level (ASL) — computeASL
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Standard Error Estimate — computeSE
text: function computes estimate standard error test statistic.

title: Standard Error Estimate — computeSE
text: x sampling replication test statistic na.rm logical value indicating whether NA     values stripped computation proceeds.

title: Standard Error Estimate — computeSE
text: numerical value, estimate standard error test statistic.

title: Standard Error Estimate — computeSE
text: computed : $$\hat{se}_{sample}(x) = \sqrt{ \frac{1}{n - 1}\sum_{=1}^{n}  {\hat{\theta}_{}}^{*} -  \hat{\theta}_{M}}^{*} $$ \(n\) number replications; \({\hat{\theta}}^{*}\) sampling replication test statistic; \({\hat{\theta}_{}}^{*}\) computed statistic \(\)-th sampled vector; \({\hat{\theta}_{M}}^{*} = \sum_{=1}^{n}{{\hat{\theta}_{}}^{*} / n} \) mean sampled statistics.

title: Standard Error Estimate — computeSE
text: Alessandro Barberis

what: Compute the Significance of the Test — computeSignificance
title: Compute the Significance of the Test — computeSignificance
text: Compute Significance Test

title: Compute the Significance of the Test — computeSignificance
code: computeSignificance(   obs,   rnd,   type = c("asl", "ci", "se"),   ci = c("standard", "percentile"),   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Compute the Significance of the Test — computeSignificance
text: obs numerical vector containing test statistic rnd numerical vector containing permutation/bootstrap statistics type character string indicating significance compute. Three options available: asl achieved significance level ci confidence interval se standard error ci character string indicating type confidence interval. Two options available: standard standard confidence interval percentile percentile confidence interval

title: Compute the Significance of the Test — computeSignificance
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
text: function computes summary score(s) signature input considering column vector input matrix x. parallel execution speed computation multi-core machine can run setting argument cores number greater 1.

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
code: computeSigScores(   x,   i = NULL,   na.rm = TRUE,   scores = c("mean", "trimmedMean", "weightedMean", "median", "mode", "midrange",     "midhinge", "trimean", "briskow", "reviewedBriskow", "IQM", "weightedSum", "ssGSEA",     "gsva", "plage", "zscore"),   sampling = c("none", "permutation", "bootstrap"),   n.repeat = 10L,   cores = 1L,   args = NULL )

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
text: x numerical matrix, features--samples (optional) numerical vector giving rows x character vector matching row names x missing = NULL, rows x considered computation score na.rm logical, whether remove NA values computation scores character vector, indicating summary score(s) compute sampling character string, indicating whether compute scores using provided data (sampling = "none", default) whether sample data. Three options available: none use x permutation random sampling without replacement bootstrap random sampling replacement n.repeat integer, number repeated samples generate cores number cores use parallel execution. args named list, names must match scores. element list another list containing arguments pass function used computing named score. example, args = list(trimmedMean = list(trim = 0.4)) indicates use trim = 0.4 computing trimmed mean score

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
text: data frame containing computed score(s) sample. row corresponds different sample. sampling = "random" sampling = "bootstrap", data frame contains column run information. two columns containing run/sample information : sampleID name sample run integer indicating run -       n.repeat - computed score

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Compute the Summary Scores — computeSigScores
code: if (FALSE) { #set seed for reproducibility set.seed(seed = 5381L)  #Define row/col size nr = 20 nc = 10  #Create input matrix x = matrix(  data = stats::runif(n = nr*nc, min = 0, max = 1000),  nrow = nr,  ncol = nc,  dimnames = list(    paste0("g",seq(nr)),    paste0("S",seq(nc))  ) )  #Compute all scores computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x)[1:10] )  #Compute one score computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x)[1:10],  scores = 'mean' )  #Compute one score passing an argument computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x)[1:10],  scores = 'trimmedMean',  args = list(trimmedMean = list(trim = 0.2)) )  #Compute scores with permutation computeSigScores(  x        = x,  i        = rownames(x)[1:10],  sampling = "permutation",  n.repeat = 10 )  #Compute scores with bootstrap computeSigScores(  x        = x,  i        = rownames(x)[1:10],  sampling = "bootstrap",  n.repeat = 10 ) }

title: Compute Correlation — computeSigScoresCorrelation
text: function computes correlation summary scores. wrapper around corr.test function.

title: Compute Correlation — computeSigScoresCorrelation
text: data data frame, output computeSigScores adjust adjustment multiple tests used? ("holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none"). See p.adjust details use "holm" rather "bonferroni"). method method="pearson" default value.  alternatives passed cor "spearman" "kendall".  last two much slower, particularly big data sets. ... arguments internal function call

title: Compute Correlation — computeSigScoresCorrelation
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: function computes approximate confidence interval point estimate (.e. test statistic).

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
code: computeStandardCi(   obs,   rnd,   conf.level = 0.95,   distribution = c("normal", "t"),   n )

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: obs numerical vector containing observed value test statistic rnd numerical vector containing permutation/bootstrap replication statistics conf.level desired confidence level distribution sampling distribution estimate. Use normal population unknown mean known variance (n large), t population unknown mean variance n sample size, used compute degrees freedom distribution = "t"

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: named numeric vector 2 elements, lower upper, lower upper bounds confidence interval point estimate.

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: confidence interval provides additional information variability point estimate generally defined $$CI = estimate \pm \textit{margin error} = estimate \pm \textit{critical value} \times \textit{standard error}$$ \(\textit{estimate}\) sample statistic estimating population parameter interest; \(\textit{critical value}\) value based sampling distribution estimate desired confidence level; \(\textit{standard error}\) standard deviation point estimate.

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5723800/

title: Standard Confidence Interval — computeStandardCi
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Looper — forLoop
text: Common interface run loop sequentially parallel. core loop defined function fun.

title: Looper — forLoop
code: forLoop(n.iter, cores = 1L, .inorder = TRUE, fun, ..., verbose = TRUE)

title: Looper — forLoop
text: n.iter number iterations loop cores number cores use parallel execution. .inorder logical flag indicating whether .combine function requires task results combined order submitted.  order important, setting .inorder FALSE can give improved performance. default value `TRUE. fun function executed inside loop. contain iloop parameter. ... arguments fun verbose logical, indicating whether R report extra information progress

title: Looper — forLoop

title: Plot Function — ggPlot
text: data data.frame containing data plot x, y, color character string, columns data describing variables mapped aesthetics x, y, color ggplot add.violin logical, whether include violin plot figure violin.data, boxplot.data, point.data data.frame containing data displayed respective layers. NULL, data inherited data add.boxplot logical, whether include boxplot figure boxplot.width numeric, width boxplot add.points logical, whether add computed scores individual summary measures points plot point.shape shape use plot scores. can take five types values: integer [0, 25] name shape single character, used plotting symbol . draw smallest rectangle visible,   usually 1 pixel NA, draw nothing See vignette("ggplot2-specs") details point.jitter.w, point.jitter.h Amount vertical horizontal jitter. jitter added positive negative directions, total spread twice value specified . See position_jitter details labs.title text title labs.x title x axis labs.y title y axis labs.col title legend axis.text.x.angle, axis.text.y.angle Specify x y axis tick labels angles ([0, 360]) See element_text details axis.text.x.size, axis.text.y.size Specify x y axis tick labels size pts. See element_text details facet.rows, facet.cols character string, variables defining faceting groups rows columns dimension. See facet_grid details ... arguments internal function call

Default: FALSE. kcdf Character string denoting kernel use non-parametric estimation               cumulative distribution function expression levels across samples method="gsva".               default, kcdf="Gaussian" suitable input expression values continuous,               microarray fluorescent units logarithmic scale, RNA-seq log-CPMs, log-RPKMs log-TPMs.               input expression values integer counts, derived RNA-seq experiments,               argument set kcdf="Poisson". ... arguments function used computing scores

title: Gene Set Variation Analysis (GSVA) Scores — gsvaScores
text: numerical vector containing computed score sample.

title: Gene Set Variation Analysis (GSVA) Scores — gsvaScores
text: function uses internally gsva GSVA R package. avoid runtime errors, x less 2 rows function returns NA.

title: Gene Set Variation Analysis (GSVA) Scores — gsvaScores
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Heatmap — heatMap
text: function generates ComplexHeatmap object. wrapper around Heatmap function.

title: Heatmap — heatMap
code: heatMap(   data,   na_col = "grey",   color_space = "LAB",   rect_gp = grid::gpar(col = "white"),   col = NULL,   column_title = character(0),   cluster_rows = TRUE,   cluster_columns = TRUE,   ... )

title: Heatmap — heatMap
text: data data frame, output computeSigScores na_col Color NA values. color_space color space colors interpolated. used matrix numeric  col vector colors. Pass colorRamp2. rect_gp Graphic parameters drawing rectangles (heatmap body). value specified gpar fill parameter ignored. col vector colors color mapping discrete color mapping  function matrix continuous numbers (generated colorRamp2). matrix continuous, value can also vector colors colors can interpolated. Pass ColorMapping. details examples, please refer https://jokergoo.github.io/ComplexHeatmap-reference/book/-single-heatmap.html#colors . column_title Title column. cluster_rows value logical, controls whether make cluster rows. value can also hclust dendrogram already contains clustering. Check https://jokergoo.github.io/ComplexHeatmap-reference/book/-single-heatmap.html#clustering . cluster_columns Whether make cluster columns? settings cluster_rows. ... arguments internal function call

title: Heatmap — heatMap
text: ComplexHeatmap object.

text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Plot Correlation of Summary Scores as Heatmap — heatmapCorSigScores
text: data data frame, output computeSigScores cor (optional) matrix containing data plot. missing, correlation matrix internally computed using default settings function computeSigScoresCorrelation scores (optional) character vector, indicating summary score(s) plot data ... arguments internal function call

title: Plot Correlation of Summary Scores as Heatmap — heatmapCorSigScores
text: ComplexHeatmap object.

title: Plot Correlation of Summary Scores as Heatmap — heatmapCorSigScores
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Plot Correlation of Summary Scores as Heatmap — heatmapCorSigScores
code: #Set seed set.seed(seed = 5381L)  #Define row/col size n = 10  #Create input matrix x = matrix(  data = stats::runif(n = n*n, min = 0, max = 1000),  nrow = n,  ncol = n,  dimnames = list(     paste0("g",seq(n)),     paste0("S",seq(n))  ) )  #Compute 5 Summary Scores x = computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x),  scores = c("mean", "median", "mode", "midrange", "midhinge") )  #Plot correlation (correlation is internally computed) heatmapCorSigScores(data = x) #> Error in cor(x, use = use, method = method): 'x' must be numeric     #Use simulated correlation matrix  #Define row/col size n = 5  #Create matrix x = matrix(  data = 1,  nrow = n,  ncol = n,  dimnames = list(    getAvailableScores()$id[1:n],    getAvailableScores()$id[1:n]  ) )  #Create data data = stats::runif(n = (((n*n)-n) / 2), min = -1, max = 1)  #Update upper triangular x[upper.tri(x = x, diag = F)] = data  #Update lower triangular to be symmetric x[lower.tri(x = x, diag = F)] = t(x)[lower.tri(x)]  #Plot heatmapCorSigScores(cor = x)

title: Interquartile Mean (IQM) Score — interquartileMeanScore
text: interquartile mean statistical measure central tendency based truncated mean interquartile range. computed : $$IQM(x) = \frac{2}{n}\sum_{=\frac{n}{4}+1}^{\frac{3n}{4}}  x_{}$$ \(x_{}\) \(\)-th element ordered vector.

title: Interquartile Mean (IQM) Score — interquartileMeanScore
text: x (named) numerical vector (optional) numerical vector giving position x character vector matching names x. missing = NULL, entire x considered computation score. na.rm unused argument, provided consistency functions.

title: Interquartile Mean (IQM) Score — interquartileMeanScore
text: numerical value representing computed score. default NA value returned score computed, values present x.

title: Interquartile Mean (IQM) Score — interquartileMeanScore
text: See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interquartile_mean

title: Interquartile Mean (IQM) Score — interquartileMeanScore

See element_text details ... arguments ggPlot

title: Plot Summary Scores as Scatter Plots — scatterplotSigScores
code: #Set seed set.seed(seed = 5381L)  #Define row/col size n = 10  #Create input matrix x = matrix(  data = stats::runif(n = n*n, min = 0, max = 100),  nrow = n,  ncol = n,  dimnames = list(     paste0("g",seq(n)),     paste0("S",seq(n))  ) )  #Compute Summary Scores x = computeSigScores(  x = x,  i = rownames(x) )  #Plot scores scatterplotSigScores(data = x) #> Warning: Removed 10 rows containing missing values (geom_point).   #Plot scatter plots per summary score scatterplotSigScores(  data       = x,  scores     = c("mean", "median"),  facet.rows = "summaryScore" )
